instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.P5VS4RS3_PGOOD: What is P5VS4RS3_PGOOD? P5VS4RS3_PGOOD is a signal that confirms the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail is working properly. .
definitions.C1950: What is C1950? Capacitor between PP3V42_G3H & ground on pin 8 of U1950 on 2013-2015 Macbook Pros & Airs that often corrodes. When corroded, pin 8 on U1950 will be damaged, which will prevent machine from booting and cause PM_SLP_S4_L to pulse. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, Fixed now missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok so I have a board on the bench that was not turning on and taking 13mA. I noticed that <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> were corroded as well as <RESISTOR>R5177</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5178</RESISTOR>. Well I replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C1950</CAPACITOR> and the board got a chime and fan spin. So I thought I would replace <RESISTOR>R5177</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5178</RESISTOR> because the ends were dark gray. SO I replaced those, touched up a couple joints on <RESISTOR>R8151</RESISTOR> and a couple others. I put the logic board back into the case and now I am back to a non working board drawing 108mA. Not sure what I did but I am missing <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_PGOOD</SIGNAL>. I am not sure what I did wrong but this is baffling. All I did was touch up some solder joints and clean the areas with IPA and a brush. I do not see anywhere where I might have knocked off a component and I wasn't brushing very hard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Power, Fixed now missing <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Never mind, It was <RESISTOR>R8151</RESISTOR>. I measured the resistance and the end cap fell off. Replaced and now have a running board. Silly...
